- Yes, my fourth-grade basketball
team is now two and oh.
Thank you for asking.
Something very weird happened recently.

Deval Patrick, the former
Governor of Massachusetts,
announced that he would not run

for the Democratic presidential
nomination in 2020.
It was, in a word, shocking.
Why?

Because virtually every
Democrat you can think of,
and lots and lots you can't think of,
are thinking about running for the chance

to take on President Donald
Trump in two years time.
Do you think I'm kidding?
Number one, I never kid.

Number two, here's a
full list of Democrats

who expressed some to a lot
of interest in the race.
Let's go.

Michael Bennett, Joe Biden,
Michael Bloomberg, Cory Booker,

Sherrod Brown, Steve
Bullock, Pete Buttigieg,

Julian Castro, John
Delaney, Tulsi Gabbard,

Eric Garcetti, Kirsten
Gillibrand, Kamala Harris,

John Hickenlooper, Eric
Holder, Jay Inslee,
John Kerry, Amy Klobuchar, Mitch Landrieu,

Terry McAuliffe, Jeff
Merkley, Chris Murphy,
Martin O'Malley, Beto O'Rourke, Tim Ryan,

Bernie Sanders, Adam
Schiff, Howard Schultz,

Tom Steyer, Eric Swalwell,
and Elizabeth Warren.
That's 31 names, 31.
And I'm sure a few names not on that list
will also wind up running.
And that's not including

the Star Wars cantina
full of total randoms

who have already filed with
the Federal Election Commission
to run for president.
My two favorites,
John Kingtamer D'Aura
and, of course, Sexy Vegan.
(clears throat) Real thing.
If you add up all the people
who are already running for president,
the list totals 422 hopefuls,

according to the indispensable
Ballotpedia website.
It's a 125 Democrats, 57 Republicans,

18 Libertarians, and 10
Green Party candidates.

And there's a wealth of
lesser-known parties in there too,

like the Commandements
Party, the YES party,
and of course, the Federalist party.
Let's get back to the 30 plus people
who actually could wind up as

the Democratic presidential
nominee against Donald Trump.

If, say, 2/3 of them,
so 20ish because math,
actually do run, they would comprise
the largest presidential field

for either party in
recent political memory.
In 2016, 17 Republicans ran for president.
In 2008, 10 Democrats ran.
Never forget Mike Gravel.
(drum boing)
Now that large number of candidates
is in stark contrast to

the relatively limited
fields in past decades.

In '92 for example, just six
Democrats ran for president.

In 1988, it was eight
on the Democratic side,
and six on the Republican side,
for a total of, eight plus six, 14,

which could be half of the
number of Democrats alone
who seek the presidency in 2020.
Now there are a few reasons for the 2020

field's likely size, some
having to do with Donald Trump,
some having to do with the nature
of our current political culture.
So the Trump reason is simple.
He looks very, very vulnerable right now.
His job approval rating is at just 40%
in the latest weekly Gallup poll.
His party, the Republican party,

just suffered through a
wave election against them,

with white suburban women
fleeing the party in droves.
And then there's the fact that Trump
actually lost the popular vote in 2016

by almost three million
votes to Hillary Clinton.
Probably didn't know that.
So there's all that.
And there is the fact that Trump,
for all the problems he's experienced
in his first two years in office,

shows roughly zero inclination
or ability to change course.
He is who he is,
which, judging from his poll numbers,

is a very good thing
for Democrats in 2020.
Now the major non-Trump reason

that more people run
for president these days
than even 20 years ago
is that it's good for business.

Given the massive interest
in politics these days,

and that is directly
attributable to Trump,

the 2020 campaign will
be the most covered ever.
Starting, well, right now, cable TV
and all of your favorite print outlets

will be covering this race
full time all the time.

Given the level of time,
attention, and money

that will flow into
the Democratic contest,

why not run for president
and see if you happen
to catch lightning in a bottle.
It can, and has, happened.
Here's an example.
Take Eric Garcetti.

He's a known quantity
in Southern California.
He's the mayor of Los Angeles.
But let's say he runs for president,
he's going to,

and manages to get some
buzz going in the race.
Even if he loses the nomination,

Garcetti could wind up on
the ticket as vice-president
in his absolute best case scenario,

or as a member of the next
Democratic president's cabinet
if he or she wins.
Now, Garcetti ain't getting anywhere near

that rarefied political air if
he just stays in Los Angeles,
or even if he, down the line,
runs for governor of California.
There is simply no springboard
like a presidential springboard,

and all of these potential
Democratic candidates know it.

Regardless of the why behind
the many Democratic candidates
who will run for president,

there's no question
that such a large field
presents a unique challenge for anyone
who is going to be in this race.
Think of it like this.
Okay, in the Kentucky Derby,

the first of three Triple
Crown races in horse racing,

the field of horses is
always really large,

because everyone and their
brother registers their horse
for that race, on the off chance
that the horse happens to win.

Now, with such a big
field, weird things happen.

The front-runner gets bumped
out of the starting gate
and never recovers, we've seen that.
Another horse can't weave its way
through traffic to the front.

A third shoots a gap caused
by a handful of horses

at the front of the pack,
all angling each other out.

A fourth can't keep up with
the pace set by the rabbit.
You get the idea.
On and on it goes.
The more people in a race for president,
the more uncertainty in that race,

the more unpredictable
moments and outcomes.
Chaos as the rule.
All of which adds up to this:
the 2020 Democratic race looks to be

the most wide open contest
for a presidential nomination
in modern history.
And that is The Point.

Make sure to check out
new episodes of The Point
every Tuesday and Thursday.
